node.text:
Hey guys, to commemorate it being over 200 years since the death of Jane Austen, I teamed up with some fellow austenites to create this fun book pass!

Featured accounts: @thatcherwine with @juniperbooks @galletas.libros  @homewardbooks @suburbancrunchygirl @hayleysolano @forget_me_not_originals @storybookstyle @lucyintheskycreations @reading_for_two @wordchild @tattooedbibliophile @vellichorblues @books_and_abe @sorrythankyou79 @_the_bookish_blonde_ @thebookboy @tattooedbibliophile @vellichorplace @galletas.libros @brenda_reads @thebookboy @jstefaniauthor @hayleysolano @suburbancrunchygirl

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on August 11, 2022. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says 'PENGUIN VITRE THE AWAKENING SELECTED THEAWAKENING STORIES KATE CHOPIN'.

node.text:
Book Review: The Awakening by Kate Chopin. (featured is the Penguin Vitae edition).

The Awakening is one of those books that has been on my radar for years even though I knew I would love it when I finally read it. I guess I was waiting for the right feeling of sort of late-summer ennui to pick it up, and I also think waiting until I was feeling like this goes a long way in explaining why I liked it so much.

In many ways the bare bones of the story has been repeated time and time again. Edna is not dissimilar from Madame Bovary and the story also feels eerily similar to Wharton's House of Mirth, of course with important differences across the three. But, to boil it down, it is effectively a strong commentary on unhappiness regardless of situation. There is an element of "oh, poor little rich girl" going on here, which is potentially why a lot of modern readers find it unpalatable. But, to be clich√©, even a gilded cage is still a cage.

Ultimately, it's a very powerful novella that is perhaps a little predictable, but also raises a lot of very important conversations at the time and even today.  4.5‚≠ê.

Have you read the Awakening? What did you think of it? What was the last book you gave 4/5 stars?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on August 10, 2022 tagging @theukbookguy. May be an image of book.

node.text:
Giveaway time!

I've joined forces with @theukbookguy to give you guys a chance to win ¬£50 towards your Amazon wishlist - basically, a lot of books üòç.

To enter:

1. Follow @thebookboy and @theukbookguy

2. Like and save this post

3. Tag two book buddies.

You can also share this post to your stories for an additional entry! (be sure to tag us both).

This giveaway will last for two weeks and end on Wednesday 24th August. The winner will be drawn the day after the giveaway ends.

Also you will only be contacted by our original accounts - don't give your details to any account claiming to be a giveaway version of us.

Good luck- may the odds be ever in your favour üòâ.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater in Ash Village. May be an image of 1 person, standing, flower and outdoors.

node.text:
Found a cute little sunflower field near home so obviously had to stage a book pic in it!

Honestly, it just feels great to be able to leave the house again without worrying about needing to dash to the bathroom - stomach bugs are above and beyond the worst things ever ü§¢.

What are you currently reading? I'm still reading my big book on Pompeii, but also The Awakening by Kate Chopin - both of which I'm really enjoying!

What are some of your favourite flowers? üåªüåªüåª

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on August 03, 2022. May be an image of book and indoor.

node.text:
My tentative August TBR!

I decided to do pink for August and have included a reread (Persuasion) as well as the new books - whether this is to erase the dubious film from my mind is yet to be seen.

Other than that, this is an interesting mix of classics, sci-fi, cli-fi and YA, so I have quite an interesting month ahead!

I've already started All The Bad Apples and it's great so far, so hoping to read more of that today if my brain works.

I currently have a vomiting bug and I also stepped in Flora's vom this morning, so you could say this is not the Wednesday of dreams üòÇ.

How is your week going? Have you read any of these? Which would you pick up first?

node.text:
July wrap up!

I blipped a bit when reading my purple books this month and picked up a couple of white ones, which meant I could make my wrap up a book shirt match too üòâ.

Unfortunately this has been a bit of a variable reading month for me in terms of quality, though there were a couple of great reads in the stack! I also read far less than usual because I've had a weirdly super busy month üòÖ

Here are my ratings:

The Village Of Eight Graves by Seishi Yokomizo - 3 stars

Candide by Voltaire - 4.5 stars

The City and the Pillar by Gore Vidal - 5 stars

Cursed Bunny by Bora Chung - 4 stars

Islands of Abandonment by Cal Flyn - 5 stars

This Charming Man by C K McDonnell - 3 stars

The Midnight Folk - 2.5 stars

Have you read any of these? Do you agree with my scores?

What colour should I read for August?

node.text:
A bit obsessed with this gorgeous @illumicrate Bridgerton set!

Admittedly, I've not read the books yet but I really like the series so I'm definitely excited to give these a go!

Have you read the Bridgerton books? How do they compare to the series?

node.text:
"The course of true love never did run smooth"

Continuing my yearly tradition of seeing lots of Shakespeare during summer, tonight I'm heading to see a production of A Midsummer Night's Dream üòç.

This is one of my favourite Shakespeare plays, so I'm definitely excited to see it live.

Did you know that in terms of number of performances A Midsummer Night's Dream is usually Shakespeare's most popular play?

It's also a play that continually gets film adaptations, with the first one being filmed in 1909!

Is it one of your favourite Shakespeare plays too?

node.text:
A little trip to Whitstable Castle!

I'm very lucky to have this beautiful place a walking distance from my office (and the beach!) - it's definitely one of my favourite reading spots in the summer üåûüåûüåû.

First built in 1790, the castle was once known as Tankerton Towers and was a family home (so it's not technically a castle, more a castellated family home). Today it's a cute wedding venue, tea room and excellent place to flomp on the lawns.

Where are some of your favourite reading spots?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 23, 2022.

node.text:
Harper Muse Painted Editions üòçüòç.

I told myself that I wasn't going to collect anymore sets of classics, but honestly these were impossible to resist!

From left to right the titles are:

The Return of Sherlock Holmes
Frankenstein
The Wizard of Oz
The Great Gatsby

Swipe to have a closer look at the covers üòä.

They also have another four titles coming in December, including Persuasion, Jane Eyre and frustratingly, Little Women (every classics collection ever has Little Women üôÑüòÇ)

Out of these four books which ones have you read? I've read all four and Frankenstein is my favourite of them üòçüòçüòç.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 23, 2022.
Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 23, 2022. May be art.
Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 23, 2022.
Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 21, 2022.

node.text:
Okay, so I have spent the last couple of days ruminating about the new Persuasion film and here are my overall thoughts. For a Janeite/Austenite like me, a new adaptation is always a huge deal so forgive me for this ramble üòÇ.

What I liked:

1. The humour - Mary especially was wonderful and parts of it definitely made me laugh.

2. The costumes (mostly). No they weren't period appropriate, but I think a lot of the looks added a quirky edge which I enjoyed.

3. Simply gorgeous scenery and locations! 

4. The general casting (except Wentworth and Anne herself, unfortunately - though Dakota was better than expected). Loved that it was a diverse cast too - more of this please!

What I didn't like:

1. Some real cringe moments (Anne peeing against a tree?! Calling music a playlist üôÑ and saying she'd dance alone to Beethoven in her room with a bottle of red (who, pray tell, would be playing the music, Anne?)

2. Lack of chemistry between the leads. I really felt like they just weren't that bothered at all for the most part - Anne had more screen chemistry with Mr Elliot.

3. Sometimes the humour fell flat and felt utterly forced.

4. Despite following the general plot, it just didn't feel like Persuasion to me, which unfortunately means I think it stepped too far away from the heart of the book.

Bonus ick points to the phrase "it's often said that if you're a 5 in London, you're a 10 in Bath" üò¨ and Lady Russell planning sexy European cruises.

Overall, I liked it more than I expected. It's certainly not the worst Austen adaptation out there (Billie Piper Mansfield Park? That weird 80s Northanger Abbey?) but it's far from the best as well. 6/10

What are your thoughts on the film? Would love to hear if you agree or disagree with my feelings on it!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Charlie Edwards-Freshwater on July 19, 2022. May be an image of 1 person, book and indoor.

node.text:
A firey book shirt stack match to match the heatwave üî•üî•üî•.

I'm actually not struggling too much today, mostly because my office has lots of fans and we're close to the sea - both of which make a huge difference, especially as it's 38 outside!

Anyway, books. What I love most about doing these stacks is I get to showcase some quite random books that don't get enough love on here.

The Honjin Murders and the Girl With All the Gifts were absolute five star reads for me, as were My Family and Other Animals and Alice in Wonderland. Perfume is one of the rare books I actually prefer the film (sacrilege I know)!

Have you read any of these? Which one would you pick up first?

How are you keeping cool this summer? üî•üåû

node.text:
Thought I'd finally give in and do a reel of my beautiful punting trip down the river stour, of course with some Enya to give with üòÇ

Had an absolute blast doing this and have decided I definitely need to do this trip again soon ‚ù§Ô∏èüòç.
